description: Constraint satisfaction puzzles including ordering people/items, positioning, scheduling, and truth-teller/liar puzzles with multiple conditions.

concepts.name: Linear Ordering
concepts.description: Arranging items or people in a sequence based on given constraints (taller than, before, to the left of)
common_misconceptions: Forgetting that 'between' means not at ends
question_patterns: [List of constraints about order]. What is the correct sequence?
Given these rules, who is in position X?
example_stems: Alex is taller than Ben. Chris is shorter than Ben. Dana is taller than Alex. Order from shortest to tallest.
Red comes before blue. Green comes after blue. Yellow is not last. What's the order?

concepts.name: Grid/Table Placement
concepts.description: Placing items in a 2D grid or table based on row and column constraints
common_misconceptions: Not checking all constraints after placement
question_patterns: Place items in the grid following these rules. What goes in position (X,Y)?
Who sits in which seat given these constraints?
example_stems: Place A, B, C, D in a 2x2 grid. A is not next to B. C is in the top row. D is in the left column.
Four students sit at a square table. Given these preferences, who sits where?

concepts.name: Scheduling Constraints
concepts.description: Assigning events or activities to time slots while satisfying all conditions
question_patterns: Schedule these activities. When does event X occur?
Given these timing constraints, what's the order of events?
example_stems: Art is before lunch. Math is after science. Science is at 10am. When is art?
Three meetings must happen today. Given constraints, what's the schedule?

concepts.name: Truth-Teller and Liar Puzzles
concepts.description: Determining who is telling truth and who is lying when each person makes a statement
question_patterns: Each person is either a truth-teller or liar. Who is telling the truth?
One person always lies, one always tells truth. What is the truth?
example_stems: Amy says 'Ben is lying.' Ben says 'Amy is lying.' One always lies. Who tells truth?
Three people make claims. At least one lies. Who is the liar?

concepts.name: Matching/Pairing Problems
concepts.description: Matching items from one set to another based on given constraints
question_patterns: Match each person to their item. Who has what?
Given these clues, pair the items correctly.
example_stems: Three people each own one pet. Given clues, who owns the cat?
Match students to subjects based on these hints.

concepts.name: Process of Elimination
concepts.description: Using given information to systematically rule out possibilities
common_misconceptions: Eliminating options too quickly without checking
Not keeping track of what's been eliminated
question_patterns: Given these facts, what must be true?
Which option is the only one that satisfies all conditions?
example_stems: The answer is not A, not C, and is a vowel. What is it?
By elimination, which person fits all the criteria?
